themes.label: Lack of real-time rostering integration and manual scheduling processes
Frequent last-minute roster changes due to unplanned absences
Desire for a user-friendly, mobile-first, real-time scheduling platform
Improve staff trust and reduce payroll discrepancies
Existing tools lack seamless integration with current workflows

learningGoals.description: Understand operational pain points caused by limited scheduling technology and manual processes
Identify features and transition support required for effective team adoption of new rostering systems

signals.headline: Manual processes and incomplete digital tools lead to operational fire-fighting and staff frustration
signals.whyItMatters: Reliance on memory and manual tracking undercuts reliability, drives inefficiencies, and increases staff burnout/turnover risk.

signals.headline: Payroll and rostering disconnects undermine staff trust and operational continuity
signals.whyItMatters: Errors affect morale, retention, and service reliability, with ripple effects seen in shift fulfillment and team motivation.

insights.question: How do you manage weekly staff scheduling, and what are the main points of friction?
insights.finding: Roster planning depends on peak hours, availability, and staff strengths, but existing tools (spreadsheets, app) are fragmented and lack real-time sync, leading to confusion and time-consuming manual work.

insights.question: What are the consequences of payroll/timesheet errors for your business?
insights.finding: Payroll errors directly impacted staff morale, trust, and created disruptions such as staff not turning up; processes have been added for review and manual double-checking.

insights.question: What would an ideal solution look like for shift scheduling in your franchise?
insights.finding: A user-friendly, mobile-accessible platform with real-time updates and training resources is prioritized to reduce learning curve and enable agility in managing shifts.

quotes.text: When planning the staff roster for the week, I typically assess peak business hours, employee availability, and any scheduled time off. I also consider individual employee strengths and preferences to ensure we have the right mix of skills on each shift, which helps with overall service quality.

Currently, I'm using a combination of spreadsheets and a scheduling app that integrates with our point-of-sale system. The spreadsheets help me track employee availability and preferences, while the app allows for easier communication and updates, although it can sometimes be glitchy, leading to confusion among staff about shifts.
I often find myself making changes to the roster weekly, primarily due to last-minute employee availability changes or unexpected absences.

When someone calls in sick, my go-to backup plan is to have a list of part-time staff who are usually available on short notice. However, it often turns into a scramble as I try to reach them and confirm their availability, especially during peak hours when everyone is busy.

One of the biggest frustrations I've faced with the current rostering tools is their lack of real-time availability updates. For instance, when a team member suddenly falls ill or has a last-minute change in schedule, it can take too long to reflect those changes in the roster, leaving us short-staffed during peak hours. Additionally, some tools don't integrate well with our existing systems, which makes it cumbersome to track employee hours and manage payroll efficiently.

Yes, I've experienced instances where timesheet errors led to staff being underpaid, which not only affected their morale but also caused delays in scheduling and trust issues within the team. For example, when a staff member didn't receive their full wages, it resulted in them calling in sick the next shift, which created staffing shortages during peak hours.

I now do a weekly review of the roster against reported hours and have a designated team member responsible for double-checking payroll submissions before they're finalized, which has significantly reduced errors.

A user-friendly design is crucial; it should be intuitive so that staff can easily navigate it without extensive training. Mobile access would also be beneficial, allowing team members to check their schedules and availability on the go. Additionally, having built-in training support, such as tutorials or FAQs, would help ease the transition and ensure everyone feels confident using the new tool.

If I could wave a magic wand, I would ensure real-time syncing between the rostering system and payroll. This would eliminate discrepancies and save a significant amount of time spent on manual adjustments.

The last major scheduling issue occurred during a holiday weekend when several staff members called in sick last minute. This left us short-staffed during peak hours. I quickly reached out to our team through a group message to see who could cover shifts, and I also brought in a part-time employee who was available.

Currently, it's more of a memory-and-hope-for-the-best approach. I do maintain a list of part-timers, but there's no systematic way to track their availability or willingness to pick up extra shifts. It can get chaotic during peak times, especially when I’m trying to recall who's already worked extra shifts that week or who's more reliable.

The biggest challenge when errors slip through is definitely the impact on staff morale and trust. When payroll discrepancies occur, it not only takes time to rectify but also creates frustration among employees, which can affect their motivation and performance.

keyInsights.insight: Manual scheduling, tool fragmentation, and lack of integration with payroll create persistent operational and morale challenges.
A real-time, user-friendly scheduling system with clear staff communication is the top requirement for operational improvement.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Hi there! Over the next 5–10 minutes, we’ll explore four topics—Current Workflow: Scheduling & Availability, Worker Availability & Reliability, Hiring & Retention Challenges, and Tools, Tech & Decision Making—to better understand how you manage shift work in a franchise-based business. Let’s get started with the first question: How do you typically go about planning your staff roster for the week, and what factors do you consider when doing so?

I also consider individual employee strengths and preferences to ensure we have the right mix of skills on each shift, which helps with overall service quality.

However, it often turns into a scramble as I try to reach them and confirm their availability, especially during peak hours when everyone is busy.
